Fig 7 Theoretical study on oxygen evolution reaction mechanism of double rare earth europium-doped graphene under hydroxyl modification in alkaline environment Tao Xu Writing – original draft Methodology Formal analysis Daomiao Wang Investigation Conceptualization Qiming Fu Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Kang Wu Methodology Conceptualization Chao Liu Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Formal analysis Investigation ⁎ School of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry, Jiangxi University of Science and Technology, Ganzhou 341000, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry Jiangxi University of Science and Technology Ganzhou 341000 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry, Jiangxi University of Science and Technology, Ganzhou 341000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The development and design of high performance OER catalyst is the key to electrocatalysis technology. Herein, based on density functional theory (DFT), the oxygen evolution reaction mechanism of double rare earth europium-doped graphene under hydroxyl modification in alkaline environment has been systematically studied. Through thermodynamic and kinetic stability analysis, and the optimal reaction path and different adsorption sites of intermediates were compared. Four catalysts with good catalytic activity for OER reaction were selected. The results show that when the two hydroxyl groups are modified, the overpotentials on the optimal pathway for the four catalyst configurations are 0.54 V, 0.50 V, 0.54 V, and 0.61 V, respectively. These catalysts demonstrate excellent catalytic activity for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Moreover, these catalysts have good electrical conductivity, and the active site and adsorption intermediates can be stably bonded together. In addition, the scaling relationship between oxygen adsorption free energy and overpotential is described. This work may provide new insights and guidance for future research on rare-earth atom-based OER catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) Double rare earth atomic catalyst Two hydroxyl group modification Alkaline environment Density functional theory (DFT) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, energy and environmental issues are important challenges facing the world. The increasing depletion of oil resources, environmental pollution and greenhouse effect have brought serious harm to human survival and health [1,2]. Therefore, the development of low-carbon emission, high conversion rate technologies, and renewable green clean energy has become an urgent priority [3–5]. Currently, metal-air batteries are widely applied in various fields due to their high efficiency, environmental friendliness, and high energy density. They are considered promising technologies [6–8]. Electrolytic water cracking is also an advanced technology for developing clean energy [9,10]. Moreover, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode play a crucial role in improving the efficiency of these batteries and developing renewable green clean energy technologies [11,12]. However, the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a complex four-electron process, accompanied by proton transfer, the kinetics is slow and the water decomposition process is limited. In catalytic reactions, it is often necessary to introduce catalysts to address the issue of sluggish kinetics [13,14]. IrO2 and RuO2 catalysts are commonly used in the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode of electrolytic cells and exhibit high catalytic activity [4]. However, its chemical stability is poor, the high cost and scarcity of Ir and Ru noble metal catalysts pose obstacles to large-scale commercial applications [15–17]. In addition, batteries are prone to corrosion in acidic environment [18]. Therefore, it is very important to design and develop alkaline environmental catalysts with low cost, high catalytic activity, high selectivity and efficiency. In the search for new catalysts with excellent catalytic performance, exploring novel alternative materials for non-noble metal catalysts is an effective approach [19–21]. With the continuous development of renewable energy technologies, atomically dispersed catalysts have emerged, offering promising prospects for achieving higher catalytic performance in OER catalysis due to their high conductivity, activity, selectivity, and atom utilization efficiency [22–24]. Single atoms are usually anchored to the carrier, in order to establish a stable catalyst model [25,26]. And the choice of different types of carriers directly influences the catalytic activity of OER. It is worth noting that two-dimensional materials have been proven to be the most promising carriers [27]. Carbon-based catalysts, such as graphene, can modulate catalytic active sites through the introduction of heteroatom doping, structural defect doping, and changes in coordination structures [28–30]. Furthermore, studies have shown that graphene-based supported single-atom catalysts, and even dual-atom catalysts, exhibit outstanding OER catalytic performance [31,32]. Of course, there are other carrier materials that combine with single atom or double atoms as electrocatalysts, which can not only show good catalytic effect of OER, but also can be used as multi-functional catalysts [33–35]. Until now, researchers have made efforts to explore various types of catalysts in order to obtain catalysts with high OER catalytic activity. However, there has been limited research on rare earth-loaded graphene catalysts. Rare earth is not rare, rich in resources, and lanthanide rare earth elements, for example, have attracted increasing attention due to their unique electronic structure and excellent electrocatalytic activity [36–38]. Among the rare earth elements, europium is one of the extensively studied elements. Its atomic orbital arrangement corresponds to a half-filled structure, where all orbitals are occupied, indicating a stable state according to the Hund's rule. Europium and its oxides have been widely applied in the field of electrocatalysis [39–41]. Moreover, rare earth elements will have better interaction with oxygen intermediates and coordination atoms, improve the adsorption efficiency and electrocatalytic performance, and promote electron transfer [42]. Therefore, there is a solid theoretical basis for achieving efficient OER catalysts by loading rare earth elements onto the defect sites of graphene. In this study, a novel approach was employed to investigate the performance of OER catalysts by designing a dual rare earth-doped defective graphene system. Graphene served as the substrate, and dual europium (Eu) atoms were loaded as the dopants, resulting in the EuEu-N x C y -gra catalyst model. Based on first-principles density functional (DFT) theory calculations, catalysts with different C/N coordination configurations were studied under alkaline conditions, and a stability screening was performed to identify catalysts with greater theoretical research value. Taking into consideration the significant adsorption strength of rare earth elements to hydroxyl groups and the presence of dual active sites, the number of hydroxyl groups adsorbed by the catalyst was tested. Then, for the selected catalysts. We will also continue to study the four-electron reaction of the water decomposition process, analyze its Gibbs free energy and adsorption energy, and determine the rate-limiting steps to calculate the overpotential. The partial density of states analysis, charge distribution and band structure were combined to explain the origin of catalyst activity. Through a series of analyses to obtain excellent OER catalyst. 2 Calculation details 2.1 Calculation models In the initial construction of the computational model, graphene was chosen as the substrate. Due to the larger atomic radius of the rare earth atoms and their dual loading form, an eight-vacancy defect configuration was designed in the middle of the graphene, and two carbon atoms were directly replaced by the rare earth atoms. The C/N coordination of the catalyst model was adjusted by means of substitution [29]. As shown in Fig. 1 a, we computationally evaluated the energy of all possible candidate configurations of N x C y -gra based on energy considerations. Subsequently, we loaded the rare-earth atom europium (Eu) into the defects of graphene and nine kinds of EuEu-N x C y -gra with low energy and good stability were selected. Table S1 shows the lowest energy corresponding to the most stable configurations of N x C y -gra. As the nitrogen coordination content increases, the energy of the corresponding configurations decreases, indicating higher stability. Interestingly, when the nitrogen coordination number is even, a certain pattern emerges, namely, configurations with symmetric nitrogen coordination have lower energy [43]. We selected these symmetric configurations for further investigation, as they facilitate better interactions between the bimetallic active sites and ligands. In this study, as shown in Fig. 1b, the rare-earth diatomic within the vacancy defects and the surrounding eight-coordinated atoms serve as the active center region of the catalyst, which play a leading role in the entire reaction process and the eight-coordinated atoms represent either nitrogen or carbon atoms. 2.2 Calculation content In this paper, a series of analysis are carried out based on the first principles theoretical calculation, all the calculated data are obtained using Dmol3 module [44]. We conducted further studies in alkaline environment with pH value is 14 and equilibrium potential is 0.402 V. In addition, more computational details are provided in the electronic supplementary information on calculation methods and calculation formulas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Stability of catalyst Excellent catalysts typically exhibit thermodynamic and kinetic stability, and a stable structure has a higher likelihood of being an excellent OER electrocatalyst. In this study, the thermodynamic stability of different catalyst configurations is determined by the binding energy (E b) and the formation energy (E f). A higher binding energy and a more negative formation energy are crucial for the thermodynamic stability of the catalyst. It is also important to ensure that the calculated binding energy is always greater than the cohesive energy (E coh = 1.86 eV). The high cohesion energy will cause atomic agglomeration, which may affect catalytic activity or even deactivation [45,46]. From Fig. 2 a, it can be observed that when the nitrogen content ranges from five to eight, the formation energy (E f) is negative, indicating the thermodynamic stability of these configurations. Moreover, the binding energy (E b) all positive, with low cohesive energy and high binding energy. This implies that the active center of these configurations can effectively anchor into vacancy defect, ensuring the stability of the catalyst. Mulliken charge analysis is an important index to describe the electronic structure and stability of catalysts [47–49]. According to the charge states in the active center region shown in Fig. S1, both bimetallic active sites carry positive charges, indicating electrons loss, while the coordinating C/N ligands carry negative charges, has the ability to obtain electrons. Additionally, N atoms possess more negative charges compared to C atoms, which conforms to the electronegativity difference between atoms [50]. Moreover, with an increasing number of N ligands, the positive charge and electron loss ability of the active site metal become more pronounced. This not only suggests a stronger bond strength between the metal and N coordination than with C coordination, but also implies that the increase in N content modulates the electronic structure of the catalyst, leading to enhanced stability of the configuration [51]. For the specific catalysts EuEu-N6C2-gra and EuEu-N8C0-gra (Fig. S1b,d), which possess a symmetrical structure, the charge amounts on the C/N ligands and metal on both sides of the active site are nearly equal, balancing the charge environment on the catalyst. This indicates that the highly symmetrical configuration exhibits strong stability, which also improves electron transfer and electrocatalytic activity [43,52]. The band diagram in Fig. S2 further demonstrates the excellent electron migration ability of these four catalysts, which are easy to electrocatalyze. From the Fig. S2a,b, it can be observed that the catalysts EuEu-N5C3-gra and EuEu-N6C2-gra have a small band gap, making electron transitions relatively easy. Generally, this does not significantly affect the rate of electron transfer. On the other hand, the valence bands of the catalysts EuEu-N7C1-gra and EuEu-N8C0-gra cross the Fermi level (Fig. S2c,d), indicating the absence of a band gap. This demonstrates their metallic nature and excellent conductivity, greatly enhancing the efficiency of electron transport. Additionally, our band gap analysis results are consistent with previous studies [53]. Through stability, charge and energy band analysis, their analytical results show that these catalysts have excellent OER catalytic performance and good structural stability. Furthermore, we carried out molecular dynamics (MD) analysis of Eu-N5C3-gra, Eu-N6C2-gra and Eu-N7C1-gra and Eu-N8C0-gra catalysts. At a temperature of 300 K, the energy change diagram with a total simulation time of 5 ps is shown in Fig. 2b-e. Throughout the simulation, the energy of these catalyst configurations remained dynamically balanced, with the structure fluctuating within a small energy range, confirming its stability. It is worth noting that as the nitrogen coordination content increases, the formation energy becomes more and more negative, and the thermodynamic stability becomes better and better. This indicates that the catalytic activity is highly correlated with the local chemical coordination environment, so these configurations can be used as good catalyst candidates [54]. 3.2 Hydroxyl effect Firstly, in order to investigate the performance of catalysts in alkaline condition, The hydroxyl adsorption strength of the four catalysts selected above was tested (Table S2). A more negative adsorption energy indicates a stronger adsorption strength. After adsorbing 1OH*, 2OH*, and 3OH*, we found that 1OH* exhibited a higher adsorption energy in the table, while the adsorption capacity of 2OH* was moderate, and the adsorption energy for 3OH* was relatively small. It is important to ensure that reactants can stably adsorb on the catalyst and desorb easily, thereby facilitating smooth reaction processes. Furthermore, the adsorption capacity of active sites is limited, and they cannot indefinitely adsorb hydroxyl groups. Therefore, for better study, we initially chose to investigate the exothermic reaction process of 2OH* adsorption using the most stable and lowest energy all-nitrogen configuration, aiming to assess the influence of the number of hydroxyl group adsorption on the catalytic performance in this study. Table S3 presents the ∆G and η values after the adsorption of 2OH* and 3OH*, where EuEu(OH)-N8C0-gra represents a hydroxyl group fixed on the catalyst to act as a ligand modification for the adsorption of OH*, O*, OOH*, O2*. We observed that when the bare graphene catalyst adsorbs an OH*, O*, OOH*, O2*, the overpotential of OER is too large to be used as a catalyst. We further consider the method of hydroxyl modification to improve the catalytic performance and reduce the overpotential. When the catalyst adsorbed 2OH*, the desorption of the hydroxyl group was an endothermic reaction and the rate-determining step of the overall reaction. This indicates that it is relatively difficult for 2OH* to desorb and transform into 1OH*, this may allow the two OH groups to be firmly anchored to the catalyst substrate. Additionally, from Table S3, we also observed that when 3OH* was adsorbed, it exhibited improved OER catalytic performance, and the entire reaction process proceeded spontaneously, and the desorption of 3OH* to 2OH* becomes easier. OER performances demonstrated more favorable catalytic effects. In addition, there are a large number of hydroxyl groups in the alkaline environment, and only one OH* reactant is adsorbed to the catalyst during the water decomposition process, which proves the possibility of 2OH* acting as ligand to modify the catalyst. After the adsorption test of these four candidate catalysts, we finally designed models of catalysts with two hydroxyl group modifications, where the third hydroxyl group serves as the reactant species for investigation [55,56]. Secondly, we need to consider which adsorption methods of the two hydroxyl groups will use to modify the catalyst. Fig. 3 shows the three potential modification modes, EuEu-N x C y -2OH-gra-right, EuEu-N x C y -2OH-gra-bridge, EuEu-N x C y -2OH-gra-left and vacancy defect of graphene substrate. According to the theoretical calculations and Tables S2 and S4, we found that when the hydroxyl groups were adsorbed on the side with an odd number of N ligands on EuEu-N5C3-2OH-gra-right and EuEu-N7C1-2OH-gra-right, the energy of the catalyst configuration was difficult to converge. Therefore, the adsorption intermediates tended to favor bridge and left-side adsorption. In addition, for EuEu-N6C2-2OH-gra and EuEu-N8C0-2OH-gra, which have symmetric configurations, the energy of both right and left adsorption modes was almost the same. There is a small energy gap. Furthermore, we observed that the energy of bridging adsorption was lower than that of left-side adsorption, indicating the feasibility of adopting the bridge adsorption reaction species. As shown in Fig. S3, this is the most optimal and energetically stable EuEu-N x C y -2OH-gra configuration among the three modification methods. We found that the active sites on one side were deeply embedded in the graphene substrate, making it difficult for reactants to bind to them. On the other side, the active site protruded prominently, fully exposing them, which forced the reactants to interact with the active sites on this side. As a result, the hydroxyl group on the bridge bond separated from the active site, and the reactant pushed the hydroxyl group from the bridge bond to the other side. Then it evolved into the phenomenon that bridge bond adsorption of intermediates. Therefore, in the case of two hydroxyl groups modification, we choose two hydroxyl groups fixed at two active sites respectively, and the reaction intermediates adsorbed on the bridge bond to carry out theoretical research on the mechanism of oxygen evolution reaction. 3.3 Adsorption of the intermediates As everyone knows, in alkaline condition, oxygen evolution reaction is 4OH− = 2H2O + O2 + 4e−. Fig. 4 shows the two excellent reaction paths (taking O2 side on adsorption as an example). Reaction steps of OER in alkaline environment: Pathway 1: OH−+* → OH* + e− OH* + OH− → O* + H2O + e− O* + OH− → OOH* + e− OOH* + OH− → O2 + H2O+* + e− Pathway 2: OH−+* → OH* + e− OH* + OH− → 2OH* + e− 2OH* + OH− → OOH* + H2O + e− OOH* + OH− → O2 + H2O+* + e− In order to investigate the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates on catalysts with dual hydroxyl modifications in alkaline conditions, a comprehensive computational analysis was conducted on the adsorption energy Δ E a d s * and adsorption free energy Δ G a d s * of the entire reaction. According to the Sabatier principle [57], catalysts should be able to adsorb oxygen molecules and oxygen-containing intermediates with moderate strength. If the adsorption is too strong, it hinders the progress of subsequent reactions and makes it difficult for the products to desorb. Conversely, if the adsorption is too weak, it hampers the interaction with the catalyst. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure an appropriate adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates to promote the smooth progression of subsequent reactions. The binding of OH to the catalyst is the first step of the entire oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and serves as a critical initial reaction step. From Table S5, considering that 3OH* is easier to desorption to 2OH*, and shows better OER catalytic performance. It can be observed that among the four catalyst configurations, the adsorption strength of the oxygen-containing intermediate OH* after binding to the bridge site is moderate, shows that its structure is stable. This suggests that it can effectively anchor within the vacancy defect of graphene. Additionally, O2* exhibits a relatively weak adsorption strength. Except for the EuEu(2OH)-N5C3-gra configuration, O2* tends to prefer side-on adsorption on the bridge site. During the process of oxygen evolution, O2* serves as the final reaction step, and the weak adsorption strength contributes to the desorption of O2*, thereby achieving the purpose of oxygen evolution. From Table S5, it was also found that when EuEu(2OH)-N x C y -gra catalyst adsorbed O, the adsorption energy and adsorption free energy of O* tended to decrease with the increase of nitrogen coordination. Taking the adsorption of O* as an example, a partial density of states (PDOS) analysis was performed on the catalyst configurations to further verify the adsorption relationship between the active sites and oxygen-containing intermediates. The PDOS of EuEu(2OH)-N x C y -O-gra as shown in Fig. S4. The p orbitals of the oxygen atom and the d and f orbitals of the rare-earth metal exhibit some hybridization peaks. Hybridized orbitals are one of the most useful concepts in valence electron theory [58]. The apparent overlap of peaks corresponding to two different orbitals at the same energy level indicate strong electron interactions between them. The energy levels are all below the Fermi level and can effective adsorption of the oxygen-containing intermediate on the active center region. The important role of d-p and f-p orbital hybridization in regulating catalytic performance was demonstrated [59]. The deformed charge density of adsorbed oxygen is shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. S5 shows the charge distribution corresponding to the deformed charge density. The isovalue was set to 0.05 electrons/Å3. The active site is surrounded by a blue electron cloud, where blue represents electron accumulation, yellow represents electron depletion. This indicates that the adsorption of the reaction intermediate O can obtain a number of electrons from the active site, and there is also a substantial electron accumulation on the coordinating C/N ligands. This demonstrates the strong interaction between C/N ligands and the metal, it has strong electron transfer [60,61]. Furthermore, on the graphene substrate, there is an alternating pattern of electron accumulation and electron depletion, indicating that the substrate can serve as both an electron donor and acceptor. This suggests that the catalyst possesses good conductivity, which is conducive to the OER catalytic reaction. Additionally, with the increase of nitrogen content, the catalyst becomes more and more stable. Here, we also take EuEu(2OH)-N5C3-gra as an example to show PDOS analysis of intermediates in the whole reaction process. As shown in Fig. S6, the p orbitals of OH, O, OOH, and O2 exhibit significant orbital overlap with the d and f orbitals of the rare-earth metal. The energy levels are all below the Fermi level. The results show that the reaction intermediates have good bonding effect with the catalysts. 3.4 Overpotential of oxygen evolution reaction The catalytic performance of the EuEu(2OH)-N x C y -gra catalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) was further analyzed in this study. The entire OER process consists of four electron-transfer steps. OER is an endothermic reaction, and the electron-transfer step with the highest heat absorption is the rate-determining step, which affects the catalytic activity of OER [62,63]. In alkaline condition, two excellent pathways (as shown in Fig. 4) were considered to investigate the reaction mechanism of the catalyst. The four potential OER catalytic processes are illustrated in Fig. 6 , where the red color represents pathway 1, the blue color represents pathway 2, the shaded green region represents the potential-determining step for pathway 1, and the shaded orange region represents the potential-determining step for pathway 2. Since the OER occurs in an alkaline environment, the reaction stages from bottom to top are endothermic, while the reverse is exothermic. The overall Gibbs free energy for the entire reaction is 1.608 eV, and the equilibrium potential is 0.402 V [64]. Combining the data from Fig. 6 and Table S6, it can be observed that on pathway 1, the potential-determining step mainly occurs in the OH*→O* electron-transfer step, while on pathway 2, it mainly occurs in the 2OH*→OOH* electron-transfer step. This indicates that these steps are the most difficult electron-transfer steps in the reaction process. Furthermore, on pathway 1, the maximum heat absorption (Gibbs free energy of the potential-determining step) from EuEu(2OH)-N5C3-gra to EuEu(2OH)-N8C0-gra catalysts is 0.94 eV, 0.90 eV, 0.94 eV, and 1.34 eV, respectively. On pathway 2, the maximum heat absorption (Gibbs free energy of the potential-determining step) from EuEu(2OH)-N5C3-gra to EuEu(2OH)-N8C0-gra catalysts is 1.71 eV, 1.45 eV, 1.30 eV, and 1.02 eV, respectively. Considering the equilibrium potential in alkaline condition is 0.402 V. According to the previously mentioned overpotential calculation formula, it can be inferred that the smaller the Gibbs free energy of the rate-determining step, the lower the overpotential, indicating better catalytic performance of the catalyst and excellent catalytic activity. Therefore, it can be concluded that the reaction on pathway 1 is more favorable and requires less energy absorption. Additionally, the rate-determining step on pathway 2 mainly occurs in the 2OH* → OOH* electron-transfer step, indicating that the breaking of the HO bond is challenging, which hinders the smooth progress of the reaction and results in poor catalytic performance. In Fig. 6, the overpotentials of EuEu(2OH)N x C y -gra on the optimal pathways are 0.54 V, 0.50 V, 0.54 V, and 0.61 V, indicating that the catalysts selected in this study exhibit excellent catalytic performance and high catalytic activity. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 7 , the adsorption free energy of oxygen has a good linear relationship with overpotential, η O E R = 0.50 Δ G O * − 1.03 , R 2 = 0.98. The error analysis for each data point is also provided in the additional table of the Fig. 7. Based on the theoretically calculated true values and the computed predicted values from the fitted linear equation, the root mean square error (RMSE) was obtained to measure the deviation between the predicted values and the true values (Cal. Value represents the predicted overpotential based on the fitted linear equation, while Err. Value represents the error between the predicted and true values) [65]. The results showed that RMSE = 0.0087, indicating a small error that effectively describes the linear relationship between adsorbate and overpotential. This highlights the significance of oxygen adsorption in catalyst performance. 4 Conclusion In this work, the OER catalytic performance of EuEu-N x C y -gra catalysts was studied by using the first principles density functional theory. Through stability analysis, four candidate catalysts were selected. Detailed research and analysis were conducted on the OER pathways and electronic structures of EuEu-N5C3-gra, EuEu-N6C2-gra, EuEu-N7C1-gra, and EuEu-N8C0-gra. The result shows that the double rare earth metal atoms europium can be stably loaded on graphene. These four configurations of EuEu-N x C y -gra exhibit good conductivity and stability, and the charge distribution in the active center region of EuEu-N x C y -gra becomes more uniform with the increasing of nitrogen coordination. Furthermore, the catalysts show strong adsorption capacity for OH* in alkaline environment. We based on energy-guided calculations, the EuEu(2OH)-N x C y -gra structure with two hydroxyl groups exhibits favorable adsorption effects in the alkaline environment which the adsorption intermediates are attached to the bridge bond. The optimal pathways for EuEu(2OH)-N5C3-gra, EuEu(2OH)-N6C2-gra, and EuEu(2OH)-N7C1-gra have overpotentials of 0.54 V, 0.50 V, and 0.54 V, respectively, all below 0.55 V, indicating their excellent OER catalytic performance. The PDOS and charge analysis also indicate that the configuration with hydroxyl ligands modified on graphene is beneficial for mitigating the strong adsorption of OH* products and enhancing the catalyst activity. This study provides new theoretical insights for the rational design of double rare earth atoms OER catalysts and offers theoretical guidance for experimental synthesis. coredata.dc:description: The development and design of high performance OER catalyst is the key to electrocatalysis technology. Herein, based on density functional theory (DFT), the oxygen evolution reaction mechanism of double rare earth europium-doped graphene under hydroxyl modification in alkaline environment has been systematically studied. Through thermodynamic and kinetic stability analysis, and the optimal reaction path and different adsorption sites of intermediates were compared. Four catalysts with good catalytic activity for OER reaction were selected. The results show that when the two hydroxyl groups are modified, the overpotentials on the optimal pathway for the four catalyst configurations are 0.54 V, 0.50 V, 0.54 V, and 0.61 V, respectively. These catalysts demonstrate excellent catalytic activity for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Moreover, these catalysts have good electrical conductivity, and the active site and adsorption intermediates can be stably bonded together. In addition, the scaling relationship between oxygen adsorption free energy and overpotential is described. This work may provide new insights and guidance for future research on rare-earth atom-based OER catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on oxygen evolution reaction mechanism of double rare earth europium-doped graphene under hydroxyl modification in alkaline environment
